edge: Boss brutally castrates an inmate and cooks and eats the testicles for 'energy food.'
Boss orders the director of The Human Centipede 2 to allow the mass suturing of inmates mouth-to-anus, forming a giant human centipede.
Six gives the prison permission to use his Centipede idea, provided that he is permitted to witness the operation.
The first two films are then shown to the inmates as a display of their future, which causes a riot.
Inmates chase Bill and Dwight to the warden's office where they beat his assistant Daisy unconscious.
Daisy is in a coma, where she is raped by Bill.
Bill shoots and kills a mentally unstable inmate eating his own feces wanting to be sewn to the centipede because he does not want anyone to enjoy the punishment.
Upon the centipede's completion, Governor Hughes arrives greatly disgusted at what he sees.
A 'Human Caterpillar' has been created by suturing together death row inmates, along with those who were given a life sentence, and amputating their limbs.
Daisy has been sewn into the Centipede
One inmate from the Centipede is in the infirmary, having been disconnected because he served his time.
The Centipede is located within the prison, and inmates from the Centipede are temporarily transferred to the infirmary.
Hughes is the creator and proponent of the Centipede punishment, which involves surgically connecting the digestive systems of multiple inmates.
Hughes believes that the death penalty is not harsh enough and advocates for the Centipede punishment as a more severe form of punishment.
Bill is a participant in the Centipede punishment, having been surgically connected to another inmate.
Dwight is also a participant in the Centipede punishment.
In anger, Bill shoots and kills Dr. Jones after Hughes leaves.
After Bill shoots and kills Dr. Jones, Dwight tries to take credit for the idea of connecting inmates together. Bill then shoots and kills Dwight.
After Hughes initially abandons the Centipede punishment, he later returns with a change of heart, stating that it is exactly what America needs.
